bibl.title: The Oldest Greek Papyrus and Writing Tablets: Fifth-Century Documents from the ‘Tomb of the Musician’ in Attica.
bibl.note: 1. The excavation of two tombs in Daphni, Odos Olgas 53, Athens [1981.] - 2. The contents of tomb 1. - 3. The contents of tomb 2. [One skeleton, a writing-case, five tablets, a papyrus roll (found complete, but now disintegrated into innumerable fragments), rests of three musical instruments (harp, lyre, aulos), 430-420 BCE.] - 4. The writing tablets. [Literary? On Α 2, 1, possibly a quotation of Hesiod, fr. 264 M.-W.] - 5. The papyrus. [Epic or lyric verse? Ionic alphabet, no clear musical notation (as the inventory book presumes).] - 6. Conclusion.
bibl.seg: 141.4 P. Piraeus Arch. Mus. Inv. ΜΠ 8520; 8523 143.4 T. Piraeus Arch. Mus. Inv. Α 27047; ΜΠ 7452; 7453; 7454; 7455
Pöhlmann Egert and Martin L. West, The Oldest Greek Papyrus and Writing Tablets: Fifth-Century Documents from the ‘Tomb of the Musician’ in Attica.

1. The excavation of two tombs in Daphni, Odos Olgas 53, Athens [1981.] - 2. The contents of tomb 1. - 3. The contents of tomb 2. [One skeleton, a writing-case, five tablets, a papyrus roll (found complete, but now disintegrated into innumerable fragments), rests of three musical instruments (harp, lyre, aulos), 430-420 BCE.] - 4. The writing tablets. [Literary? On Α 2, 1, possibly a quotation of Hesiod, fr. 264 M.-W.] - 5. The papyrus. [Epic or lyric verse? Ionic alphabet, no clear musical notation (as the inventory book presumes).] - 6. Conclusion.
